case_title: Messrs BASF CHEMICAL AND POLYMERS PAKISTAN LTD. vs TAXATION OFFICER, ACIT, KARACHI
reference_no_or_id: M.A. (Rect) No.27/KB of 2009 in I.T.A. No.167/KB of 2010
case_number: M.A. (Rect) No.27/KB of 2009 in I.T.A. No.167/KB of 2010
appellant: Messrs BASF CHEMICAL AND POLYMERS PAKISTAN LTD.
complaint_summary: The appellant sought rectification of the Tribunal's order dated 29-11-2010, claiming that two grounds of appeal were left unaddressed. Grounds included issues of audit selection without notice and jurisdictional errors under section 122(5A) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001.
investigation_summary: The Tribunal reviewed the appellant's claims and prior decisions, including a similar rectification application dismissed in 2012. It found no apparent mistake floating on the record and noted that the appellant had already challenged the main order in the High Court.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal dismissed the rectification application, stating that the issues raised had been addressed in prior orders and that the appellant had already sought remedy in the High Court. It emphasized the limited scope of rectification under section 221 of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001.

legal_arguments: Ground No.1: Selection of case for audit for Tax year 2003 without giving prior notice and without specifying reasons for selection.
Ground No.2: Amending assessment for Tax year 2003 under provisions of section 122(5A) of the Ordinance which was non-existent for said year.
Ground No.3: Amending order under section 122(5A) of the Ordinance after conducting audit under section 177 of the Ordinance.
Ground No.4: Jurisdiction of ACIT to amend order under section 122(5A) of the Ordinance.
key_observations: Rectification application on identical grounds was previously dismissed.
Scope of section 221 of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001 is restricted to mistakes apparent on the record.
Issues requiring debate or investigation fall outside the scope of rectification.
Matter is sub-judice before the Hon'ble High Court of Sindh.

questions_of_law: Whether the Tribunal was justified in confirming the action under section 122(5A) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001?
Whether the assessment framed under section 120(1) can be revised without jurisdiction?
Whether proceedings under section 122(5A) can be initiated without fulfilling pre-conditions?
Whether reopening an assessment based on change of opinion is valid?
Whether penalty under section 180 can be levied if no tax is payable?
Whether penalty under section 108 was justified without considering genuine interpretation of section 80D?

maxims.Rectification: Mistakes must be apparent and floating on the surface of the record.

legal_terms.Rectification: Correction of apparent mistakes in judicial orders.

words_and_phrases.Floating on the surface: Mistakes that are obvious and do not require investigation.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves a rectification application dismissed by the Appellate Tribunal Inland Revenue. The appellant claimed unaddressed grounds in a prior order, but the Tribunal found no apparent mistakes and noted the matter was already sub-judice in the High Court.
